protocol: Protocol for Lap Grooming Ritual: Building Trust Through Touch
description: We start by laying the puppy gently across the lap, stroking the belly — a reflex that dogs recognise from their mothers, who do this after feeding to stimulate digestion. This familiar, soothing gesture helps the dog relax and open up emotionally. Once the dog is calm, we can check the paws, ears, or even trim nails — all without fear or tension. The key is to make it a bonding ritual, not a technical task. It's something between you and your dog — a private space of care and communication.

task_sets.title: Introduction to Lap Position
task_sets.goal: Establish comfort with being held in your lap

tasks.task: Sit on the floor with your legs extended or crossed, invite dog to approach
tasks.note: Start in a relaxed, non-threatening position. Let the dog come to you.

tasks.task: Gently guide dog to sit beside you, reward with calm praise
Rest your hand on dog's side while sitting beside you for 5 seconds
Rest your hand on dog's side for 10 seconds
Gently stroke dog's side 3 times while beside you
Rest your hand on dog's side for 5 seconds
Gently encourage dog to lean against your leg, hold for 3 seconds
tasks.note: Some dogs may resist leaning. If so, just reward any weight shift toward you.

tasks.task: Dog leaning against you for 5 seconds
Stroke dog's side 5 times while leaning
Dog leaning against you for 10 seconds
Gently place one arm around dog while leaning, hold 3 seconds
tasks.note: This is a bigger commitment. If dog tenses, return to simple side contact.

tasks.task: Stroke dog's chest with free hand 3 times
Hold dog gently with arm around for 5 seconds
Hold dog gently for 10 seconds, stroke chest
Rest your hand on dog's side for 5 seconds
tasks.note: Return to easier task to reset.

tasks.task: Gently guide dog's front half onto your lap, hold 2 seconds
tasks.note: This is a significant step. Some dogs need many sessions here. If dog resists, return to leaning exercises.

tasks.task: Dog's front half on lap for 3 seconds
Dog's front half on lap for 5 seconds with gentle chest strokes
Rest your hand on dog's side for 5 seconds
Dog's front half on lap for 10 seconds
Gently stroke dog's chest and belly area 5 times
Dog resting on lap for 5 seconds
Dog resting on lap for 10 seconds
Stroke dog's side for 5 seconds
Dog resting on lap for 3 seconds

task_sets.title: Building Lap Comfort
task_sets.goal: Increase duration and comfort in lap position

tasks.task: Guide dog onto your lap, hold for 5 seconds
Dog in lap for 10 seconds with gentle stroking
Dog in lap for 5 seconds
Dog in lap for 15 seconds
tasks.note: If dog becomes restless, return to shorter durations.

tasks.task: Gently stroke from chest toward belly 5 times
Dog in lap for 10 seconds
Dog in lap for 20 seconds
Stroke dog's belly gently 3 times
tasks.note: Belly exposure is vulnerable. Watch for tension signs.

tasks.task: Dog in lap for 10 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds
Encourage dog to shift to a more reclined position, hold 3 seconds
tasks.note: We're working toward the cradled position. Go very slowly here.

tasks.task: Dog in reclined position for 5 seconds
Stroke belly gently while reclined for 5 seconds
Dog in lap for 10 seconds
Dog in reclined position for 10 seconds
Stroke from chest to belly in long, slow motions for 10 seconds
tasks.note: Use the slow, rhythmic strokes that mimic maternal care.

tasks.task: Dog in reclined position for 15 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds
Dog in reclined position for 10 seconds with belly strokes
Dog in lap for 5 seconds
Dog in lap for 3 seconds

task_sets.title: Introducing the Cradled Position
task_sets.goal: Transition to full belly-up cradled position

tasks.task: Dog in lap for 10 seconds
Dog in reclined position for 10 seconds
Gently support dog's back and encourage slight roll, hold 2 seconds
tasks.note: This is a significant trust moment. Many dogs will resist. If so, spend more time on reclined position.

tasks.task: Dog in reclined position for 5 seconds
Encourage slight roll with back support, hold 3 seconds
Gentle belly strokes while slightly rolled for 5 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds
Dog in reclined position for 10 seconds
Gently guide dog into cradled position (belly up in your arms), hold 2 seconds
tasks.note: The full cradled position. This may take many sessions. Always support the back.

tasks.task: Dog in reclined position for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 5 seconds with gentle belly strokes
Dog in lap for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Long, slow belly strokes in cradled position for 10 seconds
tasks.note: These are the maternal strokes that help dogs relax deeply.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 5 seconds
Dog in lap for 3 seconds

task_sets.title: Extended Cradling and Touch Variation
task_sets.goal: Build duration in cradled position and introduce varied touches

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds with belly strokes
Dog in cradled position for 20 seconds
Stroke from belly up toward chest 5 times
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 25 seconds
tasks.note: Building toward longer calm periods.

tasks.task: Gently rest hand on dog's chest for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Stroke dog's side while cradled for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 30 seconds
Gently touch dog's shoulder area for 3 seconds
tasks.note: Introducing touch to new areas while maintaining cradled position.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch shoulder area for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 20 seconds
Gently stroke from shoulder down toward leg 3 times
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds

task_sets.title: Introduction to Leg Handling
task_sets.goal: Begin gentle handling of front legs and paws

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Belly strokes for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 20 seconds
Gently touch front leg (upper part) for 2 seconds
tasks.note: First leg contact. If dog pulls away, return to belly strokes.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch front leg for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch front leg for 5 seconds
Gently stroke down front leg once
tasks.note: One smooth motion from shoulder to above the paw.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Stroke down front leg 3 times
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Hold front leg gently for 2 seconds
tasks.note: Very gentle hold, not restraining. Dog should be able to pull away if needed.

tasks.task: Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Hold front leg gently for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Hold front leg gently for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 5 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Hold front leg gently for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Stroke down leg to just above paw 3 times
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Gently touch paw (top only) for 1 second
tasks.note: First paw contact. Many dogs are sensitive here. If dog reacts, return to leg strokes.

tasks.task: Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch paw (top) for 2 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch paw (top) for 3 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch paw (top) for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Gently cup paw in your hand for 2 seconds
tasks.note: Not squeezing, just holding. Let the paw rest in your palm.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Cup paw in hand for 3 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Cup paw in hand for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds

task_sets.title: Paw Pad and Toe Introduction
task_sets.goal: Gentle handling of paw pads and individual toes

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Cup paw in hand for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Gently touch paw pad with thumb for 1 second
tasks.note: Paw pads can be very sensitive. Light touch only.

tasks.task: Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch paw pad for 2 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch paw pad for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch paw pad for 5 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Gently touch one toe for 1 second
tasks.note: Individual toe handling is important for nail care. Go very slowly.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch one toe for 2 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch one toe for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Gently separate toes for 1 second
tasks.note: Very gentle spreading. This is needed for checking between toes.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Separate toes gently for 2 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds

task_sets.title: Nail Handling Introduction
task_sets.goal: Prepare for nail care by handling nails without tools

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Cup paw and touch paw pad for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Gently hold one toe and touch nail for 1 second
tasks.note: First nail contact. Be very gentle and calm.

tasks.task: Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Hold toe and touch nail for 2 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Hold toe and touch nail for 3 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Hold toe and touch nail for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Gently apply light pressure to nail (as if clipping) for 1 second
tasks.note: Simulating the feeling of nail clipping without tools.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Apply light pressure to nail for 2 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch 2 different nails, 1 second each
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Touch 3 different nails, 1 second each
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Belly strokes for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Gently stroke the side of dog's head for 3 seconds
tasks.note: Working toward the ears gradually.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Stroke side of head for 5 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Gently touch base of ear for 2 seconds
tasks.note: First ear contact. Many dogs enjoy ear base massage once comfortable.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch base of ear for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Gently massage ear base for 5 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Gently touch ear flap for 2 seconds
tasks.note: Moving from base to the ear itself.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch ear flap for 3 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Hold ear flap gently for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Massage ear base for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Hold ear flap and gently lift for 2 seconds
tasks.note: Begin simulating ear checks. Very gentle lift.

tasks.task: Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Lift ear flap gently for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Lift ear flap and look inside for 3 seconds
tasks.note: Practicing the visual check you would do for ear health.

tasks.task: Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Lift ear and look inside for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Gently touch inside edge of ear (outer part only) for 2 seconds
tasks.note: Never insert anything into ear canal. Just gentle outer edge touch.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch inside edge of ear for 3 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Examine one ear for 5 seconds, then the other for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds

task_sets.title: Back Legs and Hind Paw Introduction
task_sets.goal: Extend paw handling to back legs

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Belly strokes for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Gently touch upper hind leg for 2 seconds
tasks.note: Back legs can be more sensitive. Proceed carefully.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch hind leg for 3 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch hind leg for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Stroke down hind leg once
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Stroke down hind leg 3 times
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Gently touch hind paw for 2 seconds
tasks.note: Hind paws often need more work than front paws.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch hind paw for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds

task_sets.title: Hind Paw and Nail Handling
task_sets.goal: Complete paw handling for all four feet

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Touch hind paw for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Cup hind paw in hand for 3 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Cup hind paw for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch hind paw pad for 2 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch hind paw pad for 5 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch one hind toe for 2 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch hind toe for 3 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch hind nail for 2 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch hind nail for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds

task_sets.title: Full Body Check Sequence
task_sets.goal: Practice flowing between different body areas

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 20 seconds
Belly strokes for 10 seconds
Check front paw (hold and touch pads) for 5 seconds
tasks.note: Beginning to flow between areas smoothly.

tasks.task: Belly strokes for 3 seconds
Check other front paw for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Check one ear (lift and look) for 5 seconds
Belly strokes for 3 seconds
Check other ear for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Check one hind paw for 5 seconds
Belly strokes for 3 seconds
Check other hind paw for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 20 seconds
Full belly stroke sequence for 15 seconds
tasks.note: Return to the soothing strokes as reward.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds

task_sets.title: Introduction to Grooming Tools
task_sets.goal: Introduce presence of grooming tools while maintaining calm

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Belly strokes for 10 seconds
Show nail clippers nearby (not touching dog) for 2 seconds
tasks.note: Just visual exposure. Keep clippers at a comfortable distance.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Show clippers for 3 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Show clippers for 5 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Let dog sniff clippers for 2 seconds
tasks.note: Bringing tool closer. Let dog investigate on their terms.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Let dog sniff clippers for 5 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch clippers to dog's shoulder (closed, no action) for 1 second
tasks.note: First physical contact with tool. Far from paws.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch clippers to shoulder for 2 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch clippers to leg for 2 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds

task_sets.title: Clipper Sound and Paw Contact
task_sets.goal: Introduce clipper sounds and paw contact with tool

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Belly strokes for 10 seconds
Click clippers once at distance
tasks.note: First sound exposure. Keep clippers away from dog. Some dogs are startled by the click.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Click clippers twice at distance
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Click clippers 3 times at distance
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Touch closed clippers to front paw for 1 second
tasks.note: First tool contact with paw.

tasks.task: Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Touch closed clippers to paw for 2 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Touch closed clippers to paw for 3 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Hold paw and touch clippers to nail for 1 second
tasks.note: This is significant progress. Take your time here.

tasks.task: Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Hold paw and touch clippers to nail for 2 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Dog in lap for 5 seconds

task_sets.title: Complete Grooming Ritual
task_sets.goal: Practice the full grooming ritual sequence

tasks.task: Gently guide dog into cradled position, settle for 20 seconds
tasks.note: Begin the ritual with calm settling.

tasks.task: Long, slow belly strokes for 20 seconds
tasks.note: The soothing strokes that recall mother's care.

tasks.task: Dog relaxed in cradled position for 15 seconds
Gently check right front paw - hold, examine pads, touch nails for 10 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Check left front paw for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 10 seconds
Check right ear - lift, examine, gentle touch for 10 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Check left ear for 10 seconds
Dog in cradled position for 15 seconds
Check right hind paw for 10 seconds
Belly strokes for 5 seconds
Check left hind paw for 10 seconds
Long, slow belly strokes for 20 seconds
tasks.note: Ending the ritual with the same soothing strokes we started with.

tasks.task: Dog relaxed in cradled position for 20 seconds
Gently transition dog to sitting beside you, calm praise
tasks.note: End the ritual gently. This was a bonding moment.
